visuals.title: Voltage Divider Bias — Component Layout
visuals.description: R₁ and R₂ form a divider setting V_B. R_C is the collector load. R_E provides emitter stabilisation.

visuals.title: Thévenin Equivalent of the R₁-R₂ Divider
visuals.description: The divider simplifies to V_TH = R₂/(R₁+R₂)·V_CC in series with R_TH = R₁‖R₂.

x:
Original Bias:
R₁ to V_CC, R₂ to GND

visuals.title: KVL on the Base-Emitter Loop (Thévenin Form)
Thermal Runaway: The Positive Feedback Loop (Without R_E)
visuals.description: T↑ → β↑ → I_C↑ → Power↑ → T↑ → RUNAWAY! No R_E means no counteracting force.

visuals.title: R_E Provides Negative Feedback → Self-Correction
visuals.description: T↑ → I_C↑ → V_E↑ → V_BE↓ → I_B↓ → I_C↓. The increase self-corrects!

visuals.title: Q-Point Stability: Fixed Bias vs Voltage Divider Bias
visuals.description: Fixed bias: I_C grows linearly with β. VDB with R_E: I_C is nearly flat — massive improvement.

visuals.title: Worked Example: V_CC=10V, R₁=R₂=56kΩ, R_C=10kΩ, R_E=20kΩ, β=50
Interactive: Tune Resistors and Watch the Q-Point
visuals.description: Adjust resistor values and β. Compare Q-point stability between fixed and voltage divider bias.

visuals.title: R_E Trade-off: Stability vs Voltage Headroom
visuals.description: Larger R_E → better stability but less V_CE for signal swing.

visuals.title: Fixed Bias vs Voltage Divider Bias — Comparison
visuals.description: Fixed bias: simple but β-sensitive. VDB: more components but industry standard with excellent stability.
